name: Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria (PNH) with Thrombotic Microangiopathy
chief_complaint: I feel extremely tired, my urine is dark in the morning, and I sometimes get sharp abdominal pain

lab_results.flow cytometry: CD55/CD59 deficiency on RBCs and WBCs

treatment: bone marrow transplant in refractory cases
prognosis: Variable; improved with complement inhibition therapy but risk of life-threatening thrombosis remains. 5-year survival ~65% without treatment, ~85% with eculizumab.
description: A rare, acquired hematopoietic stem cell disorder causing complement-mediated hemolysis, thrombosis, and bone marrow failure. The thrombotic microangiopathy variant presents with additional features of microvascular thrombosis leading to organ damage.
multiple_choice: Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria (PNH) with Thrombotic Microangiopathy
